Hi Oliver,

"Standing on the shoulders of giants" is only useful if it is=
 not problematic. In the Neat context, this is achieved by partitioning the=
 "building block" interior functionality from mutation. I would be very int=
erested in any published prior work, but as it appears that prior availabil=
ity of IAMION (Individually Addressable Multi-Input/Output Node) research c=
odes are seemingly sparse, I wonder if anything has progressed past proposa=
l stage. Whether LRC, SVM, network-in-a-node, ensemble population-in-a-node=
, or source code in-a-node, the first step is getting past SION (Single Inp=
ut/Output Node).

Thanks,
Andy

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Oliver Coleman=
 <oliver.coleman@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Andy,
> 
> I suspect this sort of thing=
 has been proposed before, which doesn't mean
> it shouldn't be proposed ag=
ain or in a different context, but does mean
> that perhaps there's some pr=
ior research around it.
> 
> One thing which does come to mind is that by s=
tarting with a fixed partial
> solution you are effectively starting the en=
tire population on some
> non-optimal peak in the fitness landscape, which =
is the point of your
> suggestion I think: why start at the bottom when the=
re are typically simple
> ways of getting "part way" there. However "part w=
ay" means starting on some
> non-optimal peak in a complex fitness landscap=
e; ie EAs don't follow a
> linear progression from some low point to some h=
igh point in the fitness
> landscape (except for the most trivial problems)=
: when attempting to avoid
> "reinventing the wheel" with the LRC you might=
 end up inventing the wrong
> wheel with it. Thus the population may become=
 stranded around this peak
> (depending on mutation rates, etc) and so not =
able to find better/optimal
> solutions. Of course this is a major potentia=
l problem with any EA, but I
> do wonder if starting the entire genome on s=
ome non-optimal peak would
> exacerbate the problem.
> 
> Points 4 and 5 wo=
uld go some way (perhaps a very significant way) towards
> mitigating this,=
 but I think really you just end up trading off how far up
> the non-optima=
l peak you start with how likely you are to getting stuck on
> that peak (w=
hich is perhaps your point, and not a bad thing). So, it would
> be good to=
 see some research to see how useful this sort of thing really is
> (anyone=
?).
> 
> Cheers,
> Oliver
> 
>  On 22 November 2011 09:34, afcarl2 <afcarl2=
@...> wrote:
> 
> > **
> >
> >
> > A suggestion for a generic 1st order "co=
ncept", to be held inviolate
> > withing the genome (direct or indirect enc=
oding):
> > Linear Regression/Classification (LRC) hypothesis model, based =
upon the
> > following:
> > 1) Model selection of included polynomial terms=
 based upon minimization of
> > delta error between training and cross-vali=
dation errors,
> > 2) LRC embedded within single multi-input/output node of=
 start genome,
> > 3) Start genome configured w/ LRC embedded node with inp=
ut weights of 1.0
> > to each corresponding input of genome,
> > 4) Start g=
enome configured w/ LRC embedded node with scaled output w/
> > weights of =
1.0 to each corresponding output of genome,
> > 5) Start genome configured =
w/ LRC embedded node with scaled outputs for
> > each polynomial term withi=
n the LRC model, yet not connected,
> > 6) LRC interior functionality held =
inviolate within genome,
> > The resulting start genome should have the fol=
lowing characteristics:
> > a) Start performance equivalent to LRC,
> > b) =
LRC interior complexity does not contribute to dimensional operator
> > dis=
ruption,
> > c) All significant LRC interior non-linear terms are available=
 for
> > additional complexification if justifiable,
> > The rational for t=
his suggestion as follows:
> > i. Computational overhead for development of=
 the LRC is expended once,
> > ii. Computational overhead for LRC hypothesi=
s model selection is low,
> > iii. Computational process for development of=
 the LRC is well understood,
> > iv. There is no good reason to re-invent t=
he wheel, corresponding to the
> > cost of evolving rudimentary performance=
 equivalent of the LRC in NN
> > formative elements,
> > v. LRC interior no=
n-linear terms are available for complexification, and
> > therefore do not=
 require evolutionary development from NN formative
> > elements,
> > vi. T=
he general truism, that it is usually easier/faster/quicker to modify
> > a=
nd improve something that is in-the-ballpark, than start from scratch.
> >
=
> > Andy
> >
